Award.AwardTitle: GSE/RES: Latinas in Computer Science and Engineering: A Qualitative Study Examining Identity and Agency for Resilience and Persistence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: This qualitative research investigation by an interdisciplinary team of scholars at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) is exploring factors that influence Latinas' decision to major in and persist in computer science and/or engineering as a course of study. The theoretical frame of the study includes a socio-cultural theory of identity in which identity is dynamically shaped and mediated by personal, socio-economic status, linguistic and cultural knowledge, beliefs, and values. Researchers are interviewing between 20-30 graduating seniors and 2nd year majors in depth about their experiences as computer science and/or engineering majors. Data gathering also includes participant observation protocols and focus groups. Data are analyzed using discourse analysis and life charting as interconnected interpretative practices for analysis. The expected outcome is new knowledge and theory building that could eventually inform a wide audience of stakeholders of how to support positive factors (and counter negative factors) that influence career choice and persistence among Latinas.

Broader Impacts: The proposed work will contribute to the body of knowledge and build new theories around Latinas' recruitment to, retention and completion of degrees in computer science and engineering. Currently, there is a lack of research that focuses solely on Latinas in these disciplines. The findings will lay the groundwork for further studies that can advise stakeholders of ways to modify and extend the educational and experiential approaches to broadening participation of Latinas in engineering. Understanding the mitigating factors, such as socio-economic class, language, cultural knowledge, beliefs, family dynamics and values, that influence Latinas' education and career choices in computer science and engineering could inform appropriate interventions in educational settings and outreach programs. The investigators will disseminate the results and recommendations through publications and presentations.

Institution.Name: University of Texas at El Paso
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT EL PASO

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas at El Paso

ProgramElement.Text: RES ON GENDER IN SCI & ENGINE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The motivation for the Latinas in Computer Science and Engineering study was the disproportionately low share of Latinas earning undergraduate degrees in engineering and computer science. Drawing on sociocultural theory, the research team used qualitative research methods to examine the life narratives of 26 undergraduate Latina engineering students. The research site was a public institution of higher education located on the U.S. border with Mexico where the enrollment of women in engineering is 20%, slightly higher than the national average. The overarching question driving the study was: What is the relationship among identity, resilience, and persistence of Latinas in computer science and engineering?

Whereas previous studies had focused on Latinas in predominantly White institutions, this study was situated at a Hispanic Serving Institution. Thus, this research contributes insight into how best to attract and retain women in engineering, specifically those belonging to underrepresented groups at HSIs. This research further illuminates how engineering identity development is bounded within socially legitimized values and norms with supportive others, who were primarily parents, teachers, peers, professors, and other mentors.

Like many non-traditional individuals, the Latinas in our study encountered tensions and barriers in their trajectories toward and through engineering studies, yet found support mechanisms to overcome their struggles. Thus, our major finding was the strong influence of affinity spaces and supportive individuals contributing to their interest in engineering careers and in their trajectories through engineering studies. Equally important was how engineering-related artifacts and play experiences contributed to the formation of engineering identities throughout their informal and formal educational trajectories.

Broader Impacts. The study has produced many refereed presentations and publications, more notably a chapter in SAGE Research Methods Cases-Education to be published in December 2016, and a refereed journal paper “Engineering Education through the Latina Lens” to be published in the Journal of Education and Learning in December 2016.  Paper and other presentations include the American Educational Research Association, ASEE/IEEE Frontiers in Education, American Association of Hispanics in Higher Education, and New Mexico Association for the Education of Young Children, to name a few. The diverse audiences for these presentations and publications include early childhood and K-12 educators and administrators, high school students, education researchers, engineering and computer science faculty, and higher education faculty and administrators. To ensure maximum impact, dissemination of study findings was tailored for these specific audiences, in particular specific experiential and educational instantiations from the data to inform these varied audiences.

The research methods of deep interviewing and life charting demanded critical reflection of lived experiences from the 26 Latinas who participated in the research. Thus, it is likely the research project impacted each of these 26 participants who gained new insights about themselves.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/05/2016
Modified by: Elsa Q Villa

The motivation for the Latinas in Computer Science and Engineering study was the disproportionately low share of Latinas earning undergraduate degrees in engineering and computer science. Drawing on sociocultural theory, the research team used qualitative research methods to examine the life narratives of 26 undergraduate Latina engineering students. The research site was a public institution of higher education located on the U.S. border with Mexico where the enrollment of women in engineering is 20%, slightly higher than the national average. The overarching question driving the study was: What is the relationship among identity, resilience, and persistence of Latinas in computer science and engineering? Whereas previous studies had focused on Latinas in predominantly White institutions, this study was situated at a Hispanic Serving Institution. Thus, this research contributes insight into how best to attract and retain women in engineering, specifically those belonging to underrepresented groups at HSIs. This research further illuminates how engineering identity development is bounded within socially legitimized values and norms with supportive others, who were primarily parents, teachers, peers, professors, and other mentors. Like many non-traditional individuals, the Latinas in our study encountered tensions and barriers in their trajectories toward and through engineering studies, yet found support mechanisms to overcome their struggles. The study has produced many refereed presentations and publications, more notably a chapter in SAGE Research Methods Cases-Education to be published in December 2016, and a refereed journal paper "Engineering Education through the Latina Lens" to be published in the Journal of Education and Learning in December 2016. Paper and other presentations include the American Educational Research Association, ASEE/IEEE Frontiers in Education, American Association of Hispanics in Higher Education, and New Mexico Association for the Education of Young Children, to name a few. The diverse audiences for these presentations and publications include early childhood and K-12 educators and administrators, high school students, education researchers, engineering and computer science faculty, and higher education faculty and administrators.
